articleBody: When shopping for this sunchokes recipe, you may find them under the name Jerusalem artichokes. Balsamic vinegar smacks some sass into them.
alternativeHeadline: These knobby-looking jerusalem artichokes (a.k.a. sunchokes) are sweet and nutty when browned. Balsamic vinegar smacks some sass into them.

headline: Crispy Jerusalem Artichokes with Aged Balsamic
name: Crispy Jerusalem Artichokes with Aged Balsamic
recipeIngredient: 2 pounds small Jerusalem artichokes (sunchokes), scrubbed, quartered
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a large skillet, preferably cast iron (you’ll need a lid), over medium-high heat. Add Jerusalem artichokes and ¼ cup water and season with salt and pepper. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally, until Jerusalem artichokes are fork-tender, 8–10 minutes.
Uncover skillet and cook, stirring occasionally, until water is evaporated and Jerusalem artichokes begin to brown and crisp, 8–10 minutes longer; transfer to a platter.
Add rosemary and butter to skillet and cook, stirring often, until butter foams, then browns, about 4 minutes.
Remove skillet from heat and stir in vinegar, scraping up any browned bits. Spoon brown butter sauce and rosemary over Jerusalem artichokes.
